review.title: A new approach to content-based file type detection
review.abstract: File type identification and file type clustering may be difficult tasks that have an increasingly importance in the field of computer and network security. Classical methods of file type detection including considering file extensions and magic bytes can be easily spoofed. Content-based file type detection is a newer way that is taken into account recently. In this paper, a new content-based method for the purpose of file type detection and file type clustering is proposed that is based on the PCA and neural networks. The proposed method has a good accuracy and is fast enough.

sections.heading: 3. Feature Extraction
sections.text: The problem of the optimal selection of statistical features is known as feature selection and feature extraction. While feature extraction from linear or nonlinear combinations of the original features produces a smaller number of features, feature extraction selects a subset of the original features. Feature selection transforms a data space into a feature pace that theoretically has the same dimension as the original data space. Such a transformation is practically designed so that a reduced number of effective features represents the data set while most of the intrinsic information content of the data is retained. Reducing the dimension of the input space is generally associated with a loss of information. The goal of dimensional reduction is to preserve the relevant information as much as possible. In this section, the concepts of PCA and unattended neural networks that we use for feature extraction are briefly described.
